official-title.#text: To provide exclusive funding to support fisheries and the communities that rely upon them, to clear unnecessary regulatory burdens and streamline Federal fisheries management, and for other purposes.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 3 of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 2 of the Act of August 11, 1939

header.#text: Regional Fisheries Investment Grant Program and Fishery Investment Plans

text.#text: Each Council shall establish and maintain, under the authority of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , a fishery investment committee. Each fishery investment committee shall be comprised of not more than 13 individuals.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 302(g) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act/s:302/ss:g

text.#text: develop a regional fishery investment plan under
review grant applications and projects to implement its regional fishery investment plan; and
make recommendations, based on its findings, to the Council on grant applications and projects to implement its regional fishery investment plan.
Each fishery investment committee shall—

Each member of a fishery investment committee shall be an individual who, by reason of the individual's occupational experience or other experience, scientific expertise, or training, is knowledgeable of the conservation and management of, or the commercial or recreational catch of, the fishery resources of the geographical area concerned.
shall be nominated and elected by the applicable Council during a public meeting of the Council;
shall serve for a 3-year term; and
may be re-elected for an additional 3-year consecutive term.
Each member of a fishery investment committee—
A member of a fishery investment committee shall recuse himself or herself from considering any grant application that the member has a financial interest that would require disclosure under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 302(j)(2) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act/s:302/ss:j/p:2

text.#text: the commercial fishing community;
the private recreational angling community;
the for-profit charter fishing community;
the public interest in marine conservation who—
does not derive an annual income from commercial or recreational fishing; and
is not employed by any person who derives an annual income from commercial or recreational fishing;
each State government in the region;
relevant interstate commissions;
federally recognized tribes, where applicable; and
research institutions.
Each fishery investment committee shall be multi-disciplinary, reflect the geographic balance of the Council, and include at least 1 representative of—

Each fishery investment committee shall develop a regional fishery investment plan that identifies critical research, conservation, and management needs and corresponding actions to facilitate rebuilding and maintaining healthy fish populations and sustainable fisheries over a 5-year period. Each plan shall—
be consistent with the current 5-year research priority plans developed under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 302(h)(7) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act/s:302/ss:h/p:7

text.#text: include areas of investment that are critical for rebuilding and maintaining healthy United States fish populations and promoting sustainable fisheries, including—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , involving fishery participants, academic institutions, and other interested parties;

text.#text: stock surveys, stock assessments and analysis, and cooperative fishery research, in conjunction with the
efforts to improve the collection and accuracy of fishery catch data, including—

expanding the use of, and research and development on, catch monitoring and reporting programs and technology, both at-sea and shoreside, including the use of electronic monitoring devices and satellite tracking systems; and
improving data collection for recreational fisheries, including improvements to the Marine Recreational Fishery Statistics Survey in accordance with

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 401(g)(3) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act/s:401/ss:g/p:3

text.#text: analyzing the social and economic impacts of fishery management decisions;
providing financial assistance to, and investment in, fishermen and fishing communities through—
fishing capacity reduction, including vessel, permit, and gear buybacks; and
investment in permit banks or trusts and other entities, including community fishing associations and projects designed to help sustain fishery dependent communities and small-scale fisheries;
development of methods or technologies to improve the quality and value of fish landed;
research and development of conservation engineering technologies and methods in both commercial and recreational fisheries; and
habitat restoration and protection;
be revised by the regional fishery investment committee and approved by the Council at least once every 5 years;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: for review to ensure the plan is consistent with the requirements of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall allocate 70 percent of such monies available at the beginning of each fiscal year to the 8 Council regions and the
in accordance with the following formula pursuant to

text.#text: The
One-half allocated equally among the Council regions.
One-half allocated proportionally among the Council regions based on the combined economic impact of commercial landings and recreational fishing in each region.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: for projects addressing fisheries needs and problems, as identified by the Secretary, as follows:

text.#text: 20 percent of such monies shall be available to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: deems appropriate among, the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, the Gulf States Marine Fisheries Commission, and the Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission.

text.#text: Up to one-fifth shall be allocated to, and apportioned as the
Up to one-fifth shall be allocated to seafood promotion and sustainable certification efforts.
Up to one-fifth shall be allocated to improve fisheries’ management through research, monitoring or evaluation, and modification of regulations and procedures.
Up to one-fifth shall be allocated to fisheries’ disasters, and shoreside infrastructure and access needs.
Up to one-fifth shall be allocated to other special needs, including management of highly migratory species and international fisheries.
